III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth has multiple incidents of self-harm and reports having cuts
from their shoulder to wrist. Youth reports that staff have been
informed and have not responded nor sought treatment.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed on May 29, 2024, and reported
they had no additional information.
Youth was interviewed face-to-face at the hospital on May 30,
2024, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Youth said she
has been in the hospital for two days and prior to that was placed
at Osceola Youth Center Shelter program. Youth said her DHHS
worker “stressed her out” because she was told she was going to
Vista Maria. Youth said she did not want to, and DHHS worker told
her she would “force” her to go. Youth said her DHHS worker then
went on vacation, was not around for her to talk with, and
someone she did not know was supposed to transport her to Vista
Maria which made her more upset. Youth said this made her feel
suicidal so she talked to Nurse who allowed her to call and talk to
Clinical Director. Youth said she told Clinical Director she was
feeling suicidal and “did not have the capacity to live” and that she
was feeling very unsafe. Supervisor brought her to the hospital for
an evaluation. Youth said wrote two notes, one listing the reasons
to live and one the reasons not to live however she ripped both
the notes up and threw them away. Youth denied self-harming the
day she was sent to the hospital. Youth said she felt the staff at
the facility and Clinical Director are taking her mental health
seriously. Youth said she was supposed to be transported to Vista
Maria today but now cannot go due to being in the hospital. Youth
said she called Clinical Director and said she is now feeling better
and would like to return to Osceola Youth Center Shelter program
but was told that she had to remain in the hospital until assessed.
Youth said she had cut one other time while at Osceola Youth
Center, which was “a few weeks ago”. Youth said at that time she
2

had received another upsetting phone call from her DHHS worker
about placement at Vista Maria and it “stressed her out” so she cut
several superficial marks into her arm and wrote “FAT” into her
arm. Youth said she was stressed due to needing “a new
wardrobe” prior to going to Vista Maria however not having had
time to go shopping since being placed at Osceola Youth Center.
Youth said she had a small piece of glass she found in the gravel
parking lot at the facility. Youth said another youth had broken out
a van window and despite the staff trying to get all the glass
cleaned up she still found a piece. Youth said cutting was her
“coping skill” and not done out of suicidal feelings. Youth said as
soon as she cut, she talked to Staff 1 who called and had her talk
to Assistant Facility Administrator briefly, and then she saw Nurse
who cleaned her up and placed in on 5-minute observation. Youth
said she meet with Clinical Director the following morning and she
was removed from 5-minute observation. Youth said she meets
with Clinical Director about “six times a week” and feels all the
staff take her seriously whenever she is saying she is having an
issue. Youth said all staff will complete the 5-minutes checks when
she is on that status and they will come into her room and ensure
she does not have anything unsafe, make her “shake out” her
clothing, and if under her covers in her room make her show staff
she is not harming herself.
Clinical Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
May 30, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Clinical
Director said Youth was previously placed at Osceola Youth
Center Shelter program however ended up leaving due to laying in
the road attempting to be hit by a vehicle and being sent to
inpatient hospitalization. Clinical Director said when Youth
returned to Osceola Youth Center, she immediately was placed on
5-minute observation due to arriving in the evening hours and not
being able to assess her current emotional state at that time.
Clinical Director said she completed a risk assessment the
following day and removed the heightened supervision due to the
results of Youth’s assessment as well as information provided by
her prior placement that she had not self-harmed in seven
months. Clinical Director said she also visually inspected Youth’s
arms during the initial meeting as that was where she would
normally cut herself and she had no new cuts. Clinical Director
said Youth did well for a little over a week, she had been
participating in outings and did not have any self-harm behaviors.
Clinical Director said on May 21, 2024, she received a call
regarding Youth self-harming by cutting her arm. Clinical Director
said she talked to Youth over the phone who reported it was a
coping mechanism and she reported no suicidal ideations or plans
3

to commit suicide, therefore Clinical Director said she placed her
on 5-minute observation checks. Clinical Director said when she
came into work on May 22, 2024, she completed a risk
assessment with Youth and viewed her cuts. Clinical Director said
Youth’s cuts were superficial in nature and she did not have an
elevated score for suicidal ideations or a plan to commit suicide
and therefore she was removed from 5-minute observation at that
time. Clinical Director said Youth had become very attached to
another youth at the facility and that youth did not reciprocate the
same feelings which resulted in Youth’s emotional instability and
self-harming behavior. Clinical Director said on the evening of May
28, 2024, she received a phone call from Supervisor who reported
Youth was making suicidal statements and reported having 47
ways to commit suicide. Clinical Director said she talked to Youth
over the telephone who disclosed she had a plan to lay in the road
and get hit by a vehicle and no safety plan would prevent her from
doing so, therefore Clinical Director had her brought to the
emergency room for further evaluation.
Nurse was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on June 4,
2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Nurse said a few
weeks ago Youth had an ace wrap around her arm, so she asked
her what had happened, and Youth showed her she had cut her
arm. Nurse said Youth’s cuts were superficial vertical lines and a
peer’s name scratched into her left arm. Nurse said she cleaned
Youth’s arm, disinfected it, put Neosporin on it and covered it with
a clean bandage. Nurse said Youth reported the ace wrap was
something she had in her room and was a personal belonging.
Nurse said Youth reported she cut with a small piece of glass she
found after another youth had broken a van window in the gravel
parking lot. Nurse said staff had attempted to clean all the glass
up however must have missed some. Nurse said Staff 1 was on
the unit with Youth that evening. Nurse said Youth talked to
Clinical Director who placed her on 5-minute observation. Nurse
said she informed staff and started the observation log. Nurse said
she did not know how long Youth was on 5-minute checks or if
Clinical Director assessed her the following day as Nurse said she
was not working. Nurse said a few days ago when she was
working, Supervisor came into her office and told her Youth
reported she has forty-five ways to commit suicide. Nurse said she
went to the Shelter to check on Youth and while there had her call
and talk to Clinical Director. Nurse said Youth reported to Clinical
Director she would lay in the middle of the road if left at the facility
overnight and so Clinical Director told Nurse to bring her to the
hospital for an evaluation. Nurse said she brought Youth to the
hospital and sat with her until the following morning. Nurse said
4

Clinical Director is always available to talk with the staff or youth
and always takes the youth seriously when they report any
concerns.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
June 4, 2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Supervisor
said he was not working the evening Youth cut herself a few
weeks ago however was working on May 28, 2024, when Youth
was sent to the hospital. Supervisor said Youth was on an outing
with Staff 2 when she reported she wanted too “unalive” herself.
Supervisor said Staff 2 had reported this to him when they came
back from the outing so he went and talked to Nurse regarding
what had been said. Supervisor said Nurse went to the Shelter
unit and talked to Youth and had her call Clinical Director.
Supervisor said after the phone call Youth was brought to the
hospital by Nurse for an assessment. Supervisor said he believed
Youth had additional fresh cuts on her arm the night she went to
the hospital. Supervisor said Youth had reported to Clinical
Director she was going to lay in the road if left at the facility.
Supervisor said he has no concerns about staff response to self-
harm or suicidal ideations. Supervisor said all staff take youth
seriously when they report any emotional concerns.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on June 4,
2024, in collaboration with the MDHHS worker. Staff 1 said he
was working on the detention the night Youth cut her arms. Staff 1
said he went outside and saw Youth with Staff 2 and noticed
Youth’s arms were wrapped in a bandage. Staff 1 said he asked
Youth what had happened, and she reported she cut her arms.
Staff 1 said Youth did not provide any additional details on the
cutting and he did not see it occur. Staff 1 said he was made
aware Youth had gone to the hospital on May 28, 2024, however
he was not working that evening and did not have anything to do
with that situation. Staff 1 said when a youth harms themselves
staff are supposed to intervene and stop them immediately, tend
to the wound, and tell supervisor. Staff 1 said the supervisor on
shift will then make the additional calls and direct staff what they
are supposed to do. Staff 1 said he has not had concerns that
staff ignore or do not follow protocol when youth self-harm.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on June 4,
2024, in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 said she was
working on both May 21, 2024, when Youth cut her arms, and May
28, 2024, when Youth had suicidal statements. Staff 2 said on May
21, 2024, Youth came out of the shower with a wrap on her arm.
Staff 2 said she asked Youth why she had on the wrap and Youth
5

did not answer. Staff 2 said Nurse arrived at the facility the same
time she was asking Youth about the wrap, and Youth walked over
to Nurse and told her she had cut her arms. Staff 2 said Nurse
took her to her office and took care of Youth’s arm and then
brought her back to the unit a little while later and said Youth was
on 5-minute observation. Staff 2 said she completed the 5-minute
observation for the duration of her shift however then did not work
again for five days and when she returned to work Youth was no
longer on 5-minute observation. Staff 2 said on May 28, 2024, she
brought the Shelter youth on an outing to a park. Staff 2 said
Youth did not want to go at first but once at the park Youth sat and
talked to Staff 2 about “so many things” including her past, family,
and next placement. Staff 2 said Youth told her she wanted to kill
herself and had a plan on how to die. Staff 2 said Youth talked
about wanting to go to the hospital and get an evaluation due to
how she was feeling. Staff 2 said she returned to the agency and
went and told Supervisor who then told Nurse who came and got
Youth and took her to the hospital. Staff 2 said whenever a youth
talks about suicide or has any self-harm, she immediately tells the
supervisor on shift, and they take over and make any additional
decisions and calls.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth’s Corewell Health Hospital documents dated May 28,
2024, were reviewed. The documents reported Youth being
admitted due to suicidal ideation, cooperative during her
admission, assessment completed by CMH which then
determined her stability and discharge back to Osceola
Youth Center. The medical documents reported a physical
exam was completed and did not note any concerning
lacerations.
• The Nursing Progress Notes for Youth were reviewed.
Nurse reported the superficial cuts that Youth was treated
for on May 21, 2024. Nurse’s note was consistent with her
interview.
• Youth’s Suicide Precaution and Mental health Alert
Observation Log for May 21, 2024, until May 22, 2024. The
log had observations completed within five-minute
increments as required.
• Youth’s Trauma-Informed Individualized Safety Plan dated
May 9, 2024, documented Youth was to be on Standard
Supervision and outlined her triggers and coping strategies.
• Youth’s Behavior Support Plan outlining area of positive
aspects, areas of concerns, medical concerns, services to
assist Youth, and behaviors to watch for regarding Youth.
6

• Youth’s Assessment of Suicide Risk dated May 9, 2024,
May 22, 2024, and May 28, 2024. The suicide risk
assessment’s dated May 9, 2024, and May 22, 2024,
removed Youth from close observation and placed her on
standard supervision. The suicide risk assessment dated
May 28, 2024, resulted in Youth being sent to the hospital
for an additional evaluation.
• Clinical Director’s “Clinical Chronological Note” for Youth.
The notes indicated all contacts with Youth. The notes
indicated a phone call between Clinical Director and Youth
on both May 21, 2024, and May 28, 2024, which is
consistent with Clinical Director’s interview.
• Youth’s incident report dated May 21, 2024, for self-harm
by cutting her arm, the information is consistent with Staff
2’s interview.
• Youth’s incident report dated May 28, 2024, indicating she
was brought to the hospital due to her suicidal statements
and a need for an evaluation.
• Youth Opportunity Osceola Youth Center Suicide
Prevention Plan Policy and Procedure. The policy outlines
the guidelines for identification, management, and
assessment of a potential suicide or “at risk” youth. The
policy is consistent with staff interviews regarding what to
do in the situation of self-harming, suicidal statement, or at-
risk behaviors.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff interviews, youth
interviews, and documentation review, the agency followed their
internal policy and procedure. The agency responded to and
provided Youth with care regarding self-harm and suicidal
statements on both May 21, 2024, and May 28, 2024.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: A youth at Osceola Youth Center engaged in multiple self-harm incidents and made suicidal statements. The facility's staff and clinical director responded each time by assessing the youth, providing medical care, placing her on heightened observation, and, when necessary, sending her to the hospital for evaluation. The report concludes the agency followed its internal policies and procedures appropriately in response to the youth's needs. The investigation found no violation, and no culpability is assigned to the facility as their actions were deemed compliant.
